raw_text:
Rapper films music video in jail
 
 A US rapper awaiting trial for murder has filmed part of a music video in jail, angering a sheriff who says he was tricked into letting TV crews in.
 
 C-Murder, a former member of rap group Tru, was filmed in his orange prison suit for the video for his Y'all Heard of Me single in a New Orleans jail. He is awaiting a second trial after an original conviction was thrown out. "I'm not pleased," Jefferson Parish Sheriff Harry Lee said. "He will not make another video in my jail." Footage for the video was filmed by two crews who had permission to interview C-Murder - one from Court TV and one from a local cable show.
 
 But Mr Lee said he did not know the rapper had filmed the video and made an album behind bars, and said he was fooled into letting the cameras in. The rapper's lawyer Ron Rakosky said: "The bottom line is, we didn't do anything wrong." Mr Rakosky said it was better than C-Murder, real name Corey Miller, "just sitting there, wasting away". "Here's a guy in jail, making constructive use of his time instead of withering away," he said. "He's lost more than three years of his life, locked up for a crime he did not commit."
 
 But local group Victims and Citizens Against Crime said he should not be working behind bars. "He is a suspect in a murder case. I don't think he should be allowed these privileges, especially earning money, until his name is totally cleared," the group's president Beverly Siemssen said. In 2003, C-Murder was found guilty of killing a 16-year-old in a nightclub, but that decision was thrown out last April. He is now facing a second trial on a charge of second-degree murder. With two brothers in the group Tru, he had two US top 10 albums in the late 1990s before going solo, when he scored another three top 10 albums.
llama3.2:1b: US rapper Corey Miller (C-Murder) has filmed part of his music video for "Y'all Heard of Me" in a New Orleans jail, angering Sheriff Harry Lee who claims he was tricked into letting the TV crews in. C-Murder is awaiting a second trial on a charge of second-degree murder and has been in prison since 2003. Miller's lawyer says his client is better off working behind bars, where he can "make constructive use of his time."
llama3.2:3b: US rapper C-Murder filmed part of his music video in jail while awaiting a second trial for murder after an original conviction was thrown out. The sheriff is unhappy with the decision and does not want him to film any more videos in jail.
gemma2:2b: US rapper C-Murder filmed a music video while awaiting trial for murder in a New Orleans jail. The sheriff who allowed filming denies knowing about the video and claims to be banning future filming at his facility. C-Murder's lawyer argues that it was beneficial use of time for the artist. A local group condemns this action, arguing he should not profit from criminal charges pending against him.
qwen2.5:0.5b:
A rapper filming a music video in jail angered a sheriff who says he was tricked into letting TV crews in. The rapper, C-Murder (a former member of Tru), was filmed in an orange prison suit for his Y'all Heard of Me single in New Orleans Jail. Sheriff Harry Lee said, "I'm not pleased," and asked for another video. He also said the rapper should be working instead of making music videos behind bars.

C-Murder is the real name Corey Miller, who was caught with a 16-year-old in a nightclub in 2003 but that decision was overturned last April. He faces a second trial on a charge of second-degree murder and has two US top-10 albums in the late 1990s before going solo.

Local group Victims and Citizens Against Crime said C-Murder should not be allowed behind bars, calling him a suspect in a murder case who shouldn't have these privileges.
qwen2.5:1.5b: Rapper C-Murder filmed part of a music video while awaiting trial for murder in New Orleans jail, angering Sheriff Harry Lee who claims he was tricked into letting TV crews in. The rapper says it's constructive use of time and better than sitting idle behind bars. However, victims' group opposes allowing him to work in jail until name is cleared after his conviction was overturned on second trial for murder.
qwen2.5:3b: US rapper C-Murder filmed part of his "Y'all Heard of Me" music video while awaiting trial for murder in a New Orleans jail. This angered Jefferson Parish Sheriff Harry Lee, who claimed he was tricked into allowing TV crews into the jail. C-Murder's lawyer defended the decision as constructive use of time, given the rapper's three-year wrongful incarceration. However, local group Victims and Citizens Against Crime opposes any privileges until his murder case is cleared. C-Murder previously had a successful rap career but faces another trial on second-degree murder charges.
opencoder:1.5b: The US rapper awaiting trial for murder has filmed part of a music video in jail.

With two brothers in the group Tru, he had two US top 10 albums in the late 1990s before going solo, when he scored another three top 10 albums.
